#Text=Martin Nürenbach
#Text=Martin Nürenbach or Nurembach ( unknown – 1780 ) was a German acrobat , stage actor , dancer and equilibrist active in Sweden , Norway and Finland .
#Text=He was a pioneer in Norwegian theater history by founding the first public theater in Oslo in 1771 .
#Text=Life
#Text=Early career
#Text=The early life of Martin Nürenbach is sketchy .
#Text=He was from Germany , but his year of birth is unknown .

#Text=He likely came to Sweden in the travelling theater company of the German theater director Carl Seuerling , who arrived to Sweden in 1759 , and are estimated to have been a child or a teenager at that time .
#Text=Carl Seuerling married the Swedish actress Margareta Lindahl , and took over the travelling Swedish theater company of his father-in-law Peter Lindahl , thereby staying in Sweden .
#Text=Nürenbach later stated ( 1769 ) that he was the " stepson " of Carl Seuerling , but this statement is unclear and is familial relation to Seuerling is unconfirmed . [ 1 ]
#Text=If the identification of stepson is to be taken literary , he could have been the son of Carl Seuerling 's first wife Maria Heidensköld in her previous marriage , but this is unconfirmed .
#Text=A woman by the name of Jacobina Nürembach is listed as a maid of the Seuerling theater company , and may have been a relative . [ 2 ]
#Text=Martin Nürenbach is listed as a member of the Stenborg Company in a passport to Uppsala in 1767 , and as a member of the Seuerling troupe in 1767 – 68 .
#Text=As a member of the theatre company , he performed rope- and wire-dancing and acrobatics , and identified himself as an equilibrist .
#Text=He also participated in plays as an actor , though he had only moderate success in this field .
#Text=As a member of the Stenborg and Seuerling theatre companies , he toured both Sweden and Finland , which was at that time a Swedish Province .
#Text=Nürenbach was active as a dance instructor and advertised extensively and offered dance lessons in the cities he passed on his tours , which was evidently an important side income .
#Text=He was at one point active as the " city dancing master " in Gothenburg .
#Text=At some point , he married his colleague , the dancer Anna Katarina Rancke .
#Text=Norway
#Text=In July 1770 , Martin Nürenbach made his debut as a dance teacher and performer in Oslo in Norway .
#Text=From October 1771 , he performed in companionship with the professional dancer and musician Christina Doreothea Stuart .
#Text=In the end of 1770 , he had formed a small theatre company of Norwegian stage actors .

#Text=In December 1771 , Nürenbach was given royal permission upon application to perform theatre performances in Oslo , thus founding the first permanent theatre in a city where previously only travelling theatre companies or private amateur societies similar to Det Dramatiske Selskab had performed .
#Text=Between December 1771 and February 1772 , the theatre staged a number of theatrical pieces , pantomimes , dancing , and acrobatics by Norwegian artists , performing in Danish . [ 3 ]
#Text=According to advertisements , comedies by Holberg were performed mixed with dance performances .
#Text=Not much is known of the activity of the Nürembach theatre .

#Text=Martin Nürenbach himself was evidently an appreciated and popular dancer , but not considered as good in the capacity of an actor , and it seem as if the dance performances where more appreciated than the theater plays , which is why dance performances where mixed with the plays . [ 4 ]
#Text=Aside from Nürenbach himself , nothing is known about the members of his cast , other than that they were said to have been Norwegians performing in the Danish language . [ 5 ]
#Text=Nürenbach 's wife Anna Katarina Rancke is not mentioned at all during their stay in Norway ( though it is known that she was present ) and it is unknown if she performed .
#Text=In February 1772 , the theater of Martin Nürenbach was closed and he and his wife departed Norway for Sweden .
#Text=Not long after , the Norwegian theater ban of 1738 was reintroduced in Norway , but he is noted to have closed his theater and left prior to this , of unknown causes .

#Text=The theater of Martin Nürenbach was the first permanent theater in the history of Norway and was as such a pioneer institution for which Nürenbach is remembered , though it was not to last . [ 6 ]

#Text=In 1780 , it was succeeded by the private amateur theatre Det Dramatiske Selskap , but no new public professional theater was founded in Oslo until the Christiania Offentlige Theater was founded by Johan Peter Strömberg in 1827 .
#Text=Late career

#Text=In September 1773 , Martin Nürenbach , again a member of the Stenborg Company , is known to have performed as an acrobat in the Humlegårdsteatern in Stockholm , where he made such a success that the theater company had to expand the seats of their stage building in order to give room for the large number of spectators . [ 7 ]
#Text=It was as a dancer he was famed , and performed as such after every play , but he is noted to have performed as an actor in the role of Harlequin on the 8 October .

#Text=" Nürenbach with spouse " departed as members of the Stenborg theater company to Finland , where he bought the permit to stage theater in Finland from Petter Stenborg in companionship with the actor Beckman .
#Text=From 1774 to 1780 , Nürenbach-Beckman would have been the only travelling theater company active in Finland , but not much information is known of their activity .

#Text=In 1781 , Nürenbach 's colleague Beckman returned to Stockholm where he sued Nürenbach for having broken their contract by abandoning him and taken all their actors with him : however , the court protocol simply stated that Nürenbach was " No longer present in the Kingdom .
